image.altText: Aircraft involved in firefighting in Tasmania

props.synopsis: Fires continue to burn in Tasmania's west, with multiple aircraft and ground crews involved in the effort to contain them — with authorities saying they "continue to liaise" with people who have stayed in the area.

title.children: Firefighting effort in Tasmania continues as wilderness areas burn

image.altText: Two extremely cute kittens with dark blue-grey eyes.

props.synopsis: One of Australia's five microchip and registry companies has stopped operations, warning its website is "likely to go offline".

title.children: Microchip data for tens of thousands of Australian pets at risk

image.altText: Wooden boat tied up at a jetty.

props.synopsis: Time is running out for a salvage attempt to recover a 67-year-old historic wooden boat that foundered last week before, as one expert says, the ocean floor starts to "claim" the wreck.

title.children: Salvage of sunken boat must happen soon, or ocean will 'claim' wreck

image.altText: Image of a street sign with Kunanyi Mount Wellington written on it

props.synopsis: Thirteen gazetted Aboriginal place names in Tasmania written in the reconstructed palawa kani language will have their first letter changed from lower-case to upper-case.

title.children: Tasmanian Aboriginal place names take on capitals as palawa kani 'evolves'

image.altText: The side of a large ship in port.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian government has released its revised budget estimates, showing a significant blowout in forecast debt, but the Treasurer has ruled making significant changes to its fiscal approach.

title.children: Tasmanian budget debt to hit $9.6 billion by 2027-28

image.altText: A woman with tattoos outside in the sun

props.synopsis: When Bea had an abortion, it came with a rollercoaster of emotions. Now, she's part of a team helping make sure no-one feels alone.

title.children: Talking about abortions with someone who 'just gets it'

image.altText: A large group of sail boats gathered at see with their sails up.

props.synopsis: Pacific voyaging is being celebrated at the Australian Wooden Boat festival this year, and some traditional experts hope it shines a light on the role ocean voyaging has in the fight against climate change.

title.children: Pacific voyaging shines at Hobart's Wooden Boat Festival

image.altText: Compilation of images including a Iraqi sniper firing a weapon, a brain scan and a silhouette of a man

props.synopsis: Aussie veterans who helped train Iraqi snipers say they were exposed to hundreds of blasts a day, leaving them with long-term brain injuries.

title.children: Snipers suffer irreversible damage from 'invisible shock waves'

image.altText: An aerial shot of an aluminium smelting plant, with the coastline on the horizon

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese's hopes of securing an exemption from Donald Trump's incoming metals tariffs have been dealt a blow, with a senior presidential adviser accusing Australia of "killing the aluminium market".

title.children: Trump aide says Australia 'killing aluminium market' as US tariffs loom

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaks at a press conference in brisbane

props.synopsis: Labor has been accused of reigniting its "Mediscare" campaign ahead of the federal election with a misleadingly edited attack ad in which opposition leader Peter Dutton declares "Medicare is dead".

title.children: 'Trying to create fear': Labor accused of 'disinformation' with misleading Dutton ad

image.altText: Albanese smiles, standing the prime minister's courtyard.

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese is remaining positive about the hope of an exception from Donald Trump's metal tariffs. Follow live.

title.children: PM says Trump sent 'clear signal' on tariffs despite broken promise claim

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Butler gives private health insurers deadline on premium increase

image.altText: A submarine moves through the water causing a massive wake behind it, some crew visible above deck.

props.synopsis: Former PM Malcolm Turnbull believes AUKUS is a "one-sided", bad deal, although the security partnership has cross party support in Australia. So how could the arrival of new US president Donald Trump impact the deal?

title.children: Will AUKUS survive Trump? Defence experts and critics weigh in

image.altText: A composite of a high-rise building, workers in hi-vis vests and a smiling couple.

props.synopsis: A former safety officer has blown the whistle on a culture of "fear and intimidation" within Australia's biggest apartment developer.

title.children: Meriton flouted government orders in push to build Gold Coast high-rise

image.altText: Employees of Kyushu Electric Power restart operations inside the central control room at Sendai nuclear power station

props.synopsis: As Japan grapples with new crises, nuclear power is once again being seen as the energy of the future.

title.children: 'They simply lack a plan B': Why Japan is betting big on nuclear power

image.altText: An elderly Aboriginal man looks at the camera with grey hair and a blue shirt

props.synopsis: Stolen Generations survivor Uncle Michael 'Widdy' Welsh was optimistic that change was coming when a groundbreaking national inquiry was launched to bring light to history, recognising experiences like his.

title.children: 'It’s been almost a whole generation': Survivors call on governments to act

image.altText: The outside of an aircraft printed with the letters REX in blue and orange

props.synopsis: The federal government says it is prepared to acquire Regional Express if administrators are unable to find a buyer for the collapsed airline in an upcoming sales process.

title.children: Regional Express to be government-owned if airline fails to find buyer

image.altText: A man in a suit looks at a wired technological contraption.

props.synopsis: A panel led by Tesla chair Robyn Denholm warns the nation has slipped on research and development, threatening Australia's economic future, as the industry minister says big business must take some share of the blame.

title.children: Husic points at big business over 'plummeting' research investment

props.synopsis: Around-the-clock coverage of news events as they break, at home and abroad.

title.children: Watch: News Channel

image.altText: A shop-front window and double doors are covered in political advertising.

props.synopsis: A federal politician with two offices has used taxpayer funding to open a third. The catch? It's completely empty, and by the politician's own admission "clearly a billboard".

title.children: MP under fire for using $24k office budget on election advertising

image.altText: Fare evasion

props.synopsis: Authorities have dished out more than 3,000 penalties to commuters who did not pay their 50-cent fare since prices were slashed in August.

title.children: More than $1m in fines issued since 50c public transport fares started in Qld

image.altText: CBA image

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is set to open marginally higher, while the country's biggest bank's half-year profit beats estimates. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: CBA’s first-half profit rose to $5.1 billion, beating expectations

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Are Bitcoin loans a sign crypto has gone mainstream?

image.altText: The logos of the four big banks in Australia

props.synopsis: APRA will also clarify that property developers do not need to have sold all units off the plan to get a loan.

title.children: Access to home loans to be easier for buyers with student debt

image.altText: outside view of federal court in australia

props.synopsis: A group of Canberra's social housing tenants are set to get their day in the Federal Court, with the way cleared for a class action against the ACT government over a plan to move them from their homes.

title.children: Class action by social housing tenants cleared to run

image.altText: Passengers wait for delayed trains at Central Station in Sydney.

props.synopsis: A public transport expert says industrial action planned for Sydney's train network could shift public opinion about driverless trains, as some delays are paused on the city's rail network today.

title.children: Sydney train chaos could shift public opinion towards driverless trains

image.altText: A car drives past a cyclone warning sign on the side of a country road.

props.synopsis: The category one system is expected to continue to intensify before crossing the coast later this week.

title.children: Tropical Cyclone Zelia forms off WA coast

image.altText: Steve Smith looks on during an Australia versus West Indies ODI.

props.synopsis: Steve Smith is poised to remain Australia captain in the absence of Pat Cummins, while India's Champions Trophy hopes take a hit as star quick Jasprit Bumrah is ruled out.

title.children: Smith set to keep captaincy for Champions Trophy

image.altText: Truck rolled over in floodwaters.

props.synopsis: Flood-affected residents can expect mostly dry conditions today after 11 days of severe weather and warnings for heavy rainfall.

title.children: After 11 days of heavy rainfall sunshine is on the way for north Queensland

image.altText: A drying dam with only a small amount of water in a brown, rocky landscape

props.synopsis: Rainwater tanks, dams, and springs are running dry in Adelaide Hills and Fleurieu Peninsula while water carriers say they are struggling to meet the demand from both farmers and households.

title.children: Running out of water after record low rainfall in parts of SA

image.altText: Hayden Esparon with two mates getting ready for a fishing trip

props.synopsis: Running a local men's group has brought Hayden Esparon a lot of job satisfaction. It's also helped him through some difficult times.

title.children: I help men make friends. This is what I've learnt

image.altText: Donald Trump wearing a blue suit and red tie with lips pouted mid-sentence in front of a blurred painting of George Washington

props.synopsis: Donald Trump says no nation will be exempt although there’s a prospect of Australia winning a rare reprieve from tariffs on steel and aluminium imports to the United States. Today, economist Susan Stone on the latest front in the trade wars.

title.children: ABC News Daily: Will Albanese’s call with Trump save us from tariffs?

image.altText: A close up photo of a man with an eyepatch covering one eye.

props.synopsis: The author of The Satanic Verses lost the vision in his right eye after he was stabbed in New York in 2022.

title.children: 'I thought he punched me': Salman Rushdie tells court of stabbing attack

image.altText: Up close of man with bald head in suit stares ahead

props.synopsis: The US Justice Department has ordered federal prosecutors to drop corruption charges against New York City Mayor Eric Adams.

title.children: US prosecutors ordered to drop corruption charges against New York Mayor

image.altText: Luis Rubiales wearing a dark navy suit blazer and tie sitting in a dark office chair alongside a microphone

props.synopsis: In court, Luis Rubiales denied sexual assaulting Jenni Hermoso in the aftermath of Spain's victory at the FIFA World Cup in Australia.

title.children: Luis Rubiales says Spanish football player Jenni Hermoso consented to kiss

image.altText: Four white cricket balls lying on grass.

props.synopsis: Shohely Akhter, who has played two ODIs and 13 Twenty20Is for Bangladesh, admits to breaching five provisions of the ICC's anti-corruption code.

title.children: Bangladeshi cricketer handed five-year ban for anti-corruption code breaches

image.altText: Max Richter playing a grand piano, with his eyes closed.

props.synopsis: Max Richter writes music about issues that affect us all, from getting a better night's sleep, to the importance of defending human rights. And people are listening.

title.children: Max Richter literally wrote the soundtrack for sleep. Why is his music so popular?
